sp.p: aside. Now I'm afraid she'll be tripping.

sp.speaker: DAU.
sp.p: My name was LucrisWas Lucris: He is enchanted with her name of Lucris, because it so closely resembles "lucrum," "profit" or "gain." in my own country.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: The name and the omen are worth any price. Why don't you make purchase of her? Aside. I was greatly afraid that she would be tripping. She has got herself free.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: If I make purchase of you, I trust that you'll prove Lucris to myself as well.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: If you do make purchase of her, never, on my word, do I think that she'll remain your slave throughout the month.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: And so indeed I'd hope, i' faith.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: That what you wish may come to pass, employ your own energies. Aside. In nothing even as yet has she made a slip.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: Where were you born?

sp.speaker: DAU.
sp.p: According to what my mother told me,in the kitchenIn the kitchen: This is the first of her evasions of a direct answer to Dordalus. The cleverness of all of them is admirable, and shows a wish, if possible, to save her conscience in the awkward position in which she has been placed by the gluttony of her father., in a corner on the left hand.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: to DORDALUS. This woman will prove a lucky Courtesan for you; she has been born in a warm spot, where full oft there is an abundance of all good things. Aside. The Procurer was taken in when he asked where she was born. She has played him off nicely.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: But I ask of you, what is your country?

sp.speaker: DAU.
sp.p: What should be mine but that where I now am?

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: But this I'm asking, what was?

sp.speaker: DAU.
sp.p: Everything that was, do I consider as nothing, since it was, and is not now. Just like a man when he has breathed forth his spirit; why enquire of him who he was?

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: aside. So may the Deities kindly favour me, right cleverly. And yet I really do pity her.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: But still, young woman, come, tell me at once which is your country? Why are you silent?

sp.speaker: DAU.
sp.p: For my part, I really am telling you my country. Since I'm in servitude here, this is my country.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Do cease now making enquiries about that. Don't you see that she's unwilling to declare, lest you should recall to her the remembrance of her misfortunes?

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: What's the matter? Is your father in captivity?

sp.speaker: DAU.
sp.p: Not in captivity; but what he had, he has lost.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: She will prove to be born of a good family; she knows how to say nothing but the truth.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: Who was he? Tell me his name?

sp.speaker: DAU.
sp.p: Why should I tell of him, wretched man, who he was? For the present 'twere proper for him to be called Miserable, and me Miserable.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: What kind of a person was he considered by the public?

sp.speaker: DAU.
sp.p: Not a person more acceptable; slaves and free persons all liked him.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: You do speak of a miserable man, inasmuch as he's almost lost himself, and has lost his friends.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: I shall purchase her, I think.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: What, still " I think?"

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: I imagine that she's of a noble family.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: You'll make riches by her.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: May the Gods grant it so.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Do you only buy her.

sp.speaker: DAU.
sp.p: Now this I tell you: my father will be here directly, when he knows that I've been sold, and will ransom me thus separated from him.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: What say you now Don. What's the matter?

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Do you hear what she says?

sp.speaker: DAU.
sp.p: For although his fortunes are broken, he still has friends. Pretends to cry.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: Don't weep, please; you'll soon be at liberty, if--you have sweethearts enoughHave sweethearts enough: This is a somewhat modified translation of the passage. The Procurer uses a brutal expression, which well befits his character.. Would you like to belong to me?

sp.speaker: DAU.
sp.p: So long, indeed, as I don't belong to you too long. I'd like.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: How well she does keep in mind her liberty. She'll be producing you fine hauls. About it, if you are about it. I'll go back to him. To the YOUNG WOMAN. Do you follow me. To

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: ) I've brought her back to you.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: Young man, are you disposed to sell her?

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: I'd like it, rather than lose her.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: Do you compress it then into a few words; state the price at which she's offered.

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: I'll do so, as I see you wish it. Take her for a hundred minæ.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: That's too much.

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: For eighty.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: That's too much.

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: There can't a didrachm be abated from the price which I shall now name.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: What is it, then? Speak out at once and name it.

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: At your own risk, she's offered at sixty minæ.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: Toxilus, what am I to do?

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: aside to DORDALUS. The Gods and Goddesses are pursuing you with their vengeance, you rogue, for not making haste to purchase her.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: Take them, then.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Well done, you have got a rich prize! Be off, and fetch the money out here. On my faith, she's not dear at three hundred minæ.

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: Hark you, for her clothing there'll be ten minæ added to this as well.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: Yes, be deducted, not added.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Do hold your tongue, will you; don't you see that he's seeking an excuse to have the bargain broken? Why don't you be off and fetch the money?

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: to TOXILUS, as he is going. Hark you, do you keep an eye upon him.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Why don't you then go in?

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: I'll go and fetch the money. Goes into his house.

div2.stage: The DAUGHTER of SATURIO, TOXILUS, and SAGARISTIO.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Upon my word, young lady, you have given us praiseworthy aid, good. and wise, and sensible.

sp.speaker: DAU.
sp.p: If for good persons anything good is done, the same is wont to be both important and pleasing.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Do you hear, you Persian, when you've got the money of him, do you pretend as though you are going straight to the ship.

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: Don't teach me.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Betake yourself back again to our house, that way pointing down the lane through the garden.

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: You are naming what's intended to be done.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: But don't you at once be changing your quarters with the money, I recommend you.

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: What's worthy of yourself, do you take to be worthy of me?

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Hold your tongue; lower your voice; the spoil is coming out of doors.

div2.stage: Re-enter DORDALUS, from his house, with a bag of money.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: Sixty minæ of assayed silver are here pointing at the bag, less two didrachms.

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: What's the meaning of those didrachms?

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: To pay for this bag, or else to cause it to come home again.

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: Lest you mightn't be enough of a Procurer, did you fear, wretched, filthy, avaricious creature, that you might lose your bag?

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Pray, let him alone; since he is a Procurer, he isn't doing anything surprising.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: I've judged from omens that I should make some profit to-day; nothing is of value so small to me, but that I grudge to lose it. Come, take this, will you? Holds out the bag to SAGARISTIO.

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: Place it around my neck, if it is not too much trouble.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: Certainly, it shall be done. Hangs it round his neck.

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: Is there anything else that you wish with me?

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Why are you in such haste?

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: My business is of that nature; the letters that have been entrusted me, I want to deliver; and I've heard that my twin-brother's a slave here; I wish to be off to seek him out, and redeem him.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: And, i' faith, you've not badly put me in mind of it; I think that I've seen here one very like you in figure, of just the same size.

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: Why, it must surely be my brotherBe my brother: Sagaristio is afraid that Dordalus may remember having seen him before about the city, and he artfully preoccupies the ground, by saying that he is searching for his twin-brother, whom he has lost..

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: But we'd like to know what your name is.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: What does it matter to us to know?

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p:
Listen then, that you may know; my name is Lying- speakerusLying-speakerus: He here uses an assemblage of long words made for the occasion, and coined out of Latin and Greek, hashed up together which, however, contain in themselves an account of the part which he is then acting towards the Procurer. The lines in the original are as follows:
Vaniloquidorus, Virginisvendonides,
Nugipolyloquides, Argentiexterebronides,
Tedigniloquides, Nummorumexpalponides,
Quodseme arripides, Nunquamposteareddides., Virgin-seller-onides, Trifle-great-talker-ides, Silver-screwer-outides, Thee-worthy-to-talk-to-ides, Wheedler-out-of-coin-ides, What-he-has-once-got-hold-of-ides, Never-again-part-with-it-ides.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: Dear me; upon my faith, this name of yours is written in many ways.

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: Such is the way with the Persians; we have long names of many words twisted together. Do you wish for anything else?

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: Farewell!

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: And you farewell; for my mind's aboard ship already.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: You'd better have gone to-morrow, and dined here to-day. SAGARISTIO is going. Farewell! (Exit SAGARISTIO.)

div2.stage: TOXILUS, DORDALUS, and the DAUGHTER of SATURIO.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Since that fellow's gone, I may say here whatever I please. This day has assuredly shone a gainful one for you; for you've not been buying her, but making a clear profit of her.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: He indeed quite understands what he has been about, in having sold me a stolen woman at my own risk; he has got the money, and taken himself off. How do I know now whether she mayn't be claimed at once? Whither am I to follow him? To the Persians, nonsense.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: I imagined that my services would be a cause for thankfulness with you.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: Why, yes, indeed, I do return you thanks, Toxilus, for I found that you zealously gave me your assistance.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: What, I, to you?

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: In seriousness, yes. By-the-bye, I forgot just now to give some directions in-doors, which I intended to be given. Do keep watch on her. Pointing to the YOUNG WOMAN.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: She's all safe, for certain DORDALUS goes into his house.

sp.speaker: DAU.
sp.p: My father's delaying now.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: What, if I put him in mind?

sp.speaker: DAU.
sp.p: It's full time.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: going to the side of the stage, and calling aloud. Hallo! Saturio, come forward; now's the opportunity for taking vengeance on the enemy. SATURIO.

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: See, here I am. Have I delayed at all?

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Well, go you off there at a distance out of sight; keep silence. When you see me talking to the Procurer, do you then make a row.

sp.speaker: SATURIO
sp.p: A word's enough to the wise. He withdraws out of sight.

div2.stage: Enter DORDALUS, from his house, with a whip in his hand.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: On coming into the house, I lashed them all with the whip; my house and furniture are in such a dirty state.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Are you returned at last?

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: I'm returned.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Assuredly, I have this day done you many services.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: I confess it; I give you thanks.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Do you want anything else with me?

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: That happiness may. attend you.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: I' faith, all that indeed I shall surely enjoy at home now; for I shall now go take my place at table with your freed-woman. You, when I'm gone----

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: Why don't you hold your tongue? I know what it is you want. TOXILUS goes into the house.

div2.stage: Enter SATURIO, in a seeming rage.

sp.speaker: SATURIO
sp.p: If I don't prove the destruction of that fellow----

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: I'm undone.

sp.speaker: SATURIO
sp.p: And most luckily there he is, himself, before the door.

sp.speaker: DAU.
sp.p: running towards him. Most welcome, my dear father. She embraces him.

sp.speaker: SATURIO
sp.p: Welcome, my child.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: aside. That Persian has utterly ruined me!

sp.speaker: DAU.
sp.p: to DORDALUS. This is my father.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: Ha!--what?--father? I'm utterly undone! Why then, in my misery, do I delay to bewail my sixty minæ?

sp.speaker: SATURIO
sp.p: By my faith, you scoundrel, I'll give you cause to bewail your own self as well.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: I'm undone!

sp.speaker: SATURIO
sp.p: Come, walk before a magistrate, Procurer.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: Why do you summon me before a magistrate?

sp.speaker: SATURIO
sp.p: I'll tell you there, before the Prætor. But before the magistrate I summon you.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: Don't you summonDon't you summon: See the Notes to the Curculio, l. 621. A slave, or a person of infamous character, might be dragged by force, when summoned to appear before the Prætor. a witness?

sp.speaker: SATURIO
sp.p: What, for your sake, hangdog, am I to be touching the ear of any being that's free--you, who are here trading in persons, free citizens?

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: Let me but speak----

sp.speaker: SATURIO
sp.p: I won't.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: Hear me.

sp.speaker: SATURIO
sp.p: I'm deaf. Walk on--follow me this way dragging him, you villanous mouser after maidens! Follow after me this way, my daughter, to the Prætor.

sp.speaker: DAU.
sp.p: I'll follow. Exit SATURIO, dragging DORDALUS, his DAUGHTER following.

div2.stage: Enter TOXILUS, from the house.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: to himself. The foe subdued, the citizens safe, the state in tranquillity, peace fully ratified, the war finished, our affairs prospering, the army and the garrisons untouched; inasmuch, Jupiter, and all you other Deities potent in the heavens, you have kindly aided us, for that reason do I return and give you thanks; because I have been fully revenged upon my foe. Now, for this reason, among my partners will I divide and allot the spoil. To the SLAVES in the house, who obey his orders. Come out of doors; here, before the entrance and the door, I wish to entertain my commates with hospitality. Lay down the couches here; place here the things that are usual. Here am I determined that my eagleThat my eagle: He looks upon himself as a general who has led his troops to victory; and alludes to the eagles or standards of the Roman army, which were entrusted to the Primipilus, or first Centurion of the Legion shall be first pitched; from which spot I'll cause all to become merry, joyous, and delighted, by the aid of whom those things which I wished to be effected have been rendered for me easy to be done; for worthless is the man who knows how to receive a kindness, and knows not how to return it. Enter LEMNISELENE, SAGARISTIO, and PÆGNIUM, from the house.

sp.speaker: LEMNISELENE
sp.p: My Toxilus, why am I without you? And why are you without me?

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Come then, my own one, approach me, and embrace me, please.

sp.speaker: LEMNISELENE
sp.p: Indeed I will. Embraces him.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: O, nothing is there more sweet than this. But, there's a dear, apple of my eye, why don't we at once betake us to the couches?

sp.speaker: LEMNISELENE
sp.p: Everything that you wish, the same do I desire.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: It's mutual. Come, come-come then. You, Sagaristio, recline in the upper place.

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: I don't at all care for it. Give ne but equal shares in what I've earned.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: All in good time.

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: For me that "good time" is too late.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Attend to the matter in hand. Take your place; this delightful day let's keep as a joyous birthday of mine. To the SLAVES. Bring water for our hands; arrange the table. The SLAVES obey, and the GUESTS take their places. To you, blooming one addressing LEMNISELENE, I give this blooming wreath. Places a garland on her head. You shall be our governess here. Come, lad, commence these games from the top with a round of seven cups. Bestir your hands; make haste. Pægnium, you are slow in giving me the cups; really, do give them. Here's luck to me, luck to you, luck to my mistress, luck to us all. This much wished-for day has been sent me by the Gods this day, inasmuch as I am allowed to embrace you a free woman. He drinks.

sp.speaker: LEMNISELENE
sp.p: By your own agency it was effected. Giving him the cup. This cup my hand presents to you, as it becomes a mistress to her love.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Give it me.

sp.speaker: LEMNISELENE
sp.p: Take it. Gives him the cup.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Here's luck to him who envies me, and to him who rejoices in this joy. Drinks.

div2.stage: Enter DORDALUS, at a distance.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: to himself. Those who are, and those who shall be, and those who have been, and those who are to be hereafter, all of them I singly by far surpass, in being the most wretched of men alive. I'm undone, ruined quite! This day has shone upon me the most unfortunate of days; that ruiner Toxilus has so outmanœuvred me, and has so laid waste my property! A whole cartload of silver, to my misfortune, have I upset, and lost, and have not that for which I did upset it. May all the Deities utterly confound that Persian, and all Persians, and all persons besides! in such a way has Toxilus, the wretch, conjured this up against me. Because I didn't trust him for the money, for that reason has he contrived this plan against me,--a fellow, that, by my faith, if I only live, I'll bring to torture and the fetters; if, indeed, his master ever returns here, as I trust he will. Catching sight of the REVELLERS. But what is it I see? Do look at that. What play is this? By my troth, they're carousing here surely. I'll accost them. He goes up to them. O worthy sir to TOXILUS, my greetings to you--you, too to LEMNISELENE, my worthy freed-woman.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Why surely this is Dordalus.

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: Invite him, then, to come.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: to DORDALUS. Come here, if you like. Aside. Come, let's sing his praises. Aloud. Dordalus, most delightful fellow, welcome, here's a place for you; take your place here pointing to a couch. Bring water for his feet to the SLAVES. Are you going to give it, lad? Is going to pat DORDALUS on the shoulder.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: Don't you, please, be touching me with a single finger, lest I should fell you to the ground, you villain.

sp.speaker: PÆG.
sp.p: holding up a cup. And I this very instant will be striking out your eye with this tankard.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: What do you say, gallowsGallows: "Crux." Literally, "cross;" in allusion to it as peculiarly the instrument of the punishment of slaves., you wearer-away of the whip? How have you imposed upon meImposed upon me: "Manus adita est." Literally, "your hand was gone to." This is probably an allusion to the practice of kissing the hand in irony to a person when he is loudly complaining of having been imposed upon. to-day? Into what embarrassments have you thrown me? How have I been baulked about the Persian?

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: You'll be off with your abuse from here, if you are wise.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: to LEMNISELENE. But, my worthy freed-woman, you knew of this, and concealed it from me.

sp.speaker: LEMNISELENE
sp.p: It's folly for a person who can enjoy himself to turn to brawling in preference. 'Twere more proper for you to arrange about those matters another time.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: My heart's in flames.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Give him a goblet, then; put out the fire, if his heart's in flames, that his head mayn't be burnt.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: You're making sport of me, I find.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Would you likeWould you like: This passage has been somewhat modified in the Translation. a new playfellow for you, Pægnium? Pointing at DORDALUS. But sport on as you are wont, as this is a place of freedom. PÆGNIUM struts about round DORDALUS. O rare! you do stalk in a princely style and right merrily.

sp.speaker: PÆG.
sp.p: It befits me to be merry, and I've a longing to play this Procurer some pranks, since he's deserving of it.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: As you commenced, proceed.

sp.speaker: PÆG.
sp.p: striking him. Take that, Procurer!

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: I'm undone! he has almost knocked me down!

sp.speaker: PÆG.
sp.p: Hey--be on your guardBe on your guard: In Weise's Edition, "servo," in this line, seems to be not so conformable to the sense of the passage as "serva," which has been adopted. again. Strikes at him.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: Sport on just as you please, while your master's away from here.

sp.speaker: PÆG.
sp.p: skipping around him. Don't you see how obedient I am to your request? But why, on the other hand, are not you obedient to my request as well, and why don't you do that which I advise you?

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: PÆG.
sp.p: Do you take a stout rope for yourself, and go hang yourself.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: shaking his stick. Take you care, will you, that you don't touch me, lest I give you a heavy return with this walking-stick. PÆG. Make use of it; I give you leave.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Come, come, Pægnium, put an end to it.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: By my faith, I'll utterly destroy you all.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: But he, who dwells aboveWho dwells above: He alludes to Jupiter, the King of Heaven. us, wishes you all ill, and will do you all ill. It's not they that tell you so, but I.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Come to the SLAVES, carry round the honied wineThe honied wine: He probably mentions "mulsum," because that was the draught with which soldiers were regaled after victory.; give us drink in goblets quite full: it's a long time now since we last drank; we've been athirst too long.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: May the Gods grant that you may drink that which may never pass through you.

sp.speaker: PÆG.
sp.p: I cannot forbear, Procurer, from at least dancing a hornpipeA hornpipe: "Staticulum." This was probably danced, the performer not moving from the spot; and perhaps was something similar to our hornpipe dances. Of Hegea and Diodorus, the dancing masters, no records are left. for you, which Hegea formerly composed. But just look if it quite pleases you. He dances.

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: rising. I'd like also to repeat that one which Diodorus formerly composed in Ionia. Goes close to DORDALUS.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: I'll be doing you a mischief, if you are not off!

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: Still muttering, impudence? If you provoke me, I'll just now be bringing you the Persian again.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: I' faith, I'm silenced now. Why, you are the Persian that has been fleecing me to the quick!

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Hold your tongue, simpleton; this is his twin-brother.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: Is it he? Tox. Aye, and a very twin of twins.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: May the Gods and Goddesses rack both yourself and your twin-brother.

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: Him, you mean, who has been ruining you; for I don't deserve anything.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: But still, what he deserves, I hope that that may prove to your undoing.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: to SAGARISTIO. Come, if you like, let's have some sport with this fellow, unless he isn't deemed worthy of it.

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: Just now it's right.

sp.speaker: LEMNISELENE
sp.p: aside. But it isn't proper for me.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: aside. For the reason, I suppose, that he made no difficulties when I purchased you.

sp.speaker: LEMNISELENE
sp.p: aside. But still----

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: aside. No "still." Beware, then, of a mishap, will you, and obey me. It becomes you to be heedful of my orders; for, i' faith, had it not been for me and my protection, he would before long have made a street-walker of you. But such are some of those who have gained their freedom, unless they thwart their patron, they don't appear to themselves free enough, or wise enough, or honest enough, unless they oppose him, unless they abuse him, unless they are found ungrateful to him who has been kind.

sp.speaker: LEMNISELENE
sp.p: aside. I' troth, your kindnesses command me to pay obedience to your commands.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: aside. I clearly am your patron, who paid the money for you to that man pointing to DORDALUS; in return for that, I choose that he shall be made sport of.

sp.speaker: LEMNISELENE
sp.p: aside. For my part, I'll do my utmost.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: For sure, these persons are consulting to do something, I know not what, to injure me.

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: Hark you.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: What do you say?

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: Is this person here, Dordalus the Procurer, who deals in free women? Is this he who was formerly st stalwart?

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: What means this? PÆGNIUM strikes him. Oh, oh! he has given me a slap in the face! I'll do you a mischief. Shakes his fist at him.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: But we have done you one, and shall do it again too.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: PÆGNIUM pinching him. Oh, oh! he's pinching my behind.

sp.speaker: PÆG.
sp.p: Of course; it has been many a time twitched before this.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: Are you still prating, you bit of a boy?

sp.speaker: LEMNISELENE
sp.p: to DORDALUS. My patron, do, there's a dear, come in-doors to dinner.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: My lump of laziness, are you now scoffing at me?

sp.speaker: LEMNISELENE
sp.p: What, because I invite you to enjoy yourself?

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: I don't want to enjoy myself.

sp.speaker: LEMNISELENE
sp.p: Then don't.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: How then? The six hundred didrachms, how are they? What disturbances they do cause.

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: aside. I'm utterly undone! They understand full well how to return the compliment to an enemy.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: Have we now had satisfaction enough?

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: I confess it; I hold up my handsHold up my hands: "Manus dare," "to extend the hands," was a term applied to the gladiators in the Amphitheatres, who extended their hands for mercy, when they acknowledged themselves defeated. to you.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: And, ere long, you shall be holding them beneath the bilboesBeneath the bilboes: "Furca." This instrument, in shape of the letter V, was placed round the neck of offenders, and their hands tied to the ands of it.. Be off in-doors.

sp.speaker: SAGARISTIO
sp.p: To perdition!

sp.speaker: DORDALUS
sp.p: to the AUDIENCE. Have these fellows here worked me in too slight a degree? Goes into his house.

sp.speaker: TOXILUS
sp.p: calling after him. Keep in mind that you met with a Toxilus. To the AUDIENCE. Spectators, kindly fare you well. The Procurer is demolished. Grant us your applause.
